Award.AwardTitle: Demographic History Inference from Genomic Linkage and Allele Frequency Spectra
Award.AbstractNarration:
When did human populations separate from each other? Did they go through bottlenecks? How much migration has there been between them? Answers to these questions about demographic history are encoded in the distribution of mutations within and between human populations. Sequences of entire genomes from hundreds of humans from around the world are now available, but reading the history recorded in these genomes requires new tools. This research will develop a computational method for learning demographic history from genomes that takes a novel approach to simulating not only the frequencies of mutations, but also the correlations between them. This research will also leverage existing genomic data to infer a detailed model for the demographic history of human populations within Africa, with a focus on Pygmy hunter-gatherers and neighboring agriculturalists.

Understanding African demographic history is key to understanding our species, because humans originated in Africa, and because Africa harbors more human diversity than any other region of the world. The demographic models developed in this research will unveil history and provide a framework for investigating human genetic adaptation to diverse environments. The computational method developed in this research will be applicable not only to humans, but also to other species. The method will be freely shared over the Internet, providing a powerful new tool for the population genomics community. In addition, the research will support and provide interdisciplinary training for a postdoctoral scientist, a graduate student, and two undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the development and application of tools for learning about evolutionary history from present-day genomes. Sequencing multiple individuals from one or more populations reveals the distribution of mutations within and between those populations. That distribution depends on the evolutionary history of those populations, so we can learn about the past by identifying historical models that can produce the present-day distribution of mutations.

A major outcome of this project was the development of a new tool for modeling natural selection at sites that contain more than one mutation. Such sites are relatively rare, but they are very informative about how selection acts. In particular, we applied this tool to fruitfly data to quantify how similar the typical selective effects are of mutations at the same protein site. Remarkably, our result from fruitfly genomes agrees with direct experiments in bacteria and yeast, suggesting that the similarity we found is a fundamental feature of protein evolution. We think that this insight into protein evolution will be broadly useful, particularly in understanding the evolution of bacteria and viruses that affect human health.

We also dramatically improved the statistical capabilities of our existing tools for modeling genomic history. Previous approaches tended to be overconfident, because mutations in the genome interact but that interaction is too complex to model. That overconfidence could be corrected, but only with very intensive computer simulation. We developed a much more efficient approach and integrated it into our widely used tool, ensuring that other researchers will not be led astray by overconfident results.

Our major application was to reveal the evolutionary history of Pygmy humans living in Central Africa. Using sequenced genomes from 7 Pygmies and 4 farmers, we built a model for the history of these populations, characterizing when and how they diverged from each other. We then used that model as a baseline to identify regions of the genome that distinguish Pygmies from farmers and regions that arose from interbreeding with extinct relatives of modern humans. We also collaborated with conservation geneticists to show that a particular population of desert tortoises was genetically isolated from other tortoises, establishing it as a separate species deserving of focused conservation efforts.

During this project, two graduate students and one programmer were trained in the analysis of genomic data. In addition, the principle investigator developed an undergraduate course that introduces biology students to the many applications of mathematics and computing in biology.
